title: Land Yet to Possess
shortSummary: Joshua 13 records God's command to Joshua to divide the remaining land yet to be possessed by Israel, detailing the territories east of the Jordan River and those still unconquered west of it. The chapter emphasizes God's faithfulness in giving the land as an inheritance to the tribes, while also highlighting the Levites' unique role without a land inheritance.
timeline: c. 1406 BC - The Conquest of Canaan under Joshua's leadership after the Exodus

keyCharacters.name: Joshua
keyCharacters.description: The leader of Israel after Moses, tasked with dividing the Promised Land among the tribes.

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The servant of the LORD who previously allocated land east of the Jordan to the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and half of Manasseh.

keyCharacters.name: Sihon
keyCharacters.description: King of the Amorites whose land east of the Jordan was given to Israel after being defeated by Moses.

keyCharacters.name: Og
keyCharacters.description: King of Bashan, a remnant of the giants, whose territory was also conquered and given to the tribe of Manasseh.

keyCharacters.name: Balaam
keyCharacters.description: The soothsayer slain by Israel, mentioned as part of the conquest east of the Jordan.

definitions.definition: The land or possessions given by God to the tribes of Israel as their rightful possession.
A method used to fairly divide land or possessions among the tribes, symbolizing God's sovereign distribution.
The tribe of Levi, set apart for priestly duties, who received no territorial inheritance but the LORD Himself as their portion.
Refers to the Rephaim, a race of large and mighty people defeated by Israel, including King Og.

outline.heading: God's Command to Joshua and Remaining Land to Possess
outline.description: God informs Joshua that despite his old age, much land remains to be conquered and instructs him to divide this land among the tribes, emphasizing the ongoing fulfillment of God's promise.

outline.heading: Land East of Jordan Given to Reuben, Gad, and Half-Manasseh
outline.description: A detailed description of the territories east of the Jordan River assigned to the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh, including cities and regions conquered from Amorite kings Sihon and Og.

outline.heading: The Levites’ Unique Inheritance
outline.description: The Levites receive no land inheritance; instead, their inheritance is the LORD Himself, highlighting their spiritual role and dependence on God rather than territorial possession.

application: Trust in God's timing and faithfulness even when tasks seem incomplete or challenging, as Joshua was old but still had work to do.
Recognize the importance of obedience in claiming God's promises, as Israel was commanded to possess the land by dividing it according to God's instructions.
Value spiritual inheritance and service to God above material possessions, following the example of the Levites who received God Himself as their portion.
Commit to faithfully stewarding what God has given, whether land, resources, or spiritual gifts, for His glory and the benefit of His people.

keyVerses.text: Now Joshua was old and stricken in years; and the LORD said unto him, Thou art old and stricken in years, and there remaineth yet very much land to be possessed.
keyVerses.significance: This verse sets the stage for the chapter, showing God's ongoing plan despite Joshua's advanced age.

keyVerses.text: Only unto the tribe of Levi he gave none inheritance; the sacrifices of the LORD God of Israel made by fire are their inheritance, as he said unto them.
keyVerses.significance: Highlights the unique spiritual role of the Levites and God's provision for them apart from land.

keyVerses.text: But unto the tribe of Levi Moses gave not any inheritance: the LORD God of Israel was their inheritance, as he said unto them.
keyVerses.significance: Reaffirms the Levites’ special status and dependence on God rather than earthly possessions.
